indicators.justification:
While it is a welcome development that visualised data is available for emissions information (1), the best practice would be to publish these data in open data format, which the government agency in charge is not doing at the moment. It would be much appreciated by civil society if the responsible government agency publish the spreadsheets along with the visualization tool for best practice. Data is only available from 2018, although it is stated in the law that it is meant to be updated every three years. There is no data available from 2021. Therefore the answer to this question has been answered "no".

Source:

(1) https://air.emb.gov.ph/emission-inventory-2018/

evidence.title: Philippine Clean Air Act of 1999
2018 Emission Inventory - Philippine Department of Environment and Natural Resources
Philippine Policies for Air Quality and Management

indicators.justification:
Great strides towards publishing beneficial ownership data are being done by multi-sector transparency initiatives like the Philippine Extractives Industry Transparency Initiative(PH-EITI)(1). Unfortunately, for the Securities and Exchange Commission, this is not the norm. In fact, it closed down its I-View Registry (2), where these datasets could have been available for the public, and will cover all corporations across sectors.

Sources:

(1) https://pheiti.dof.gov.ph/boregistry/
(2) https://www.sec.gov.ph/online-services/sec-i-view/

evidence.title: Extractives Beneficial Ownership September 2020 PH-EITI

indicators.justification:
The Philippine Department of Health's COVID-19 Tracker does include some data on healthcare system capacity, but unfortunately, it is not updated in real-time and updating periods can vary per facility. Efforts to make published information in open data format, however, can be seen, and should be acknowledged, through the department's daily COVID-19 Data Drop (1).

Sources:

(1) https://data.gov.ph/search/field_topic/Health-1057

indicators.justification:
While there are efforts from the Philippine Statistics Authority to make land ownership-related datasets available online, these do not include those related to land tenure. Data on land tenure remains in the custody of different government agencies, and the data available remain unconnected, uncorroborated, and not free (1).

Also, due to lack of data on indigenous peoples and minorities and under the guise of COVID-19 there has been escalation of violence over land rights issues in the Philippines [2].

[https://aippnet.org/philippines-ips-group-ncip-stop-denial-vote-for-un-probe/](https://aippnet.org/philippines-ips-group-ncip-stop-denial-vote-for-un-probe/)

Source:

(1) https://angoc.org/news/csos-discuss-land-data-in-the-philippines-in-the-context-of-the-sustainable-development-goals/

(2) https://aippnet.org/philippines-ips-group-ncip-stop-denial-vote-for-un-probe

evidence.title: Philippine Statistics Authority - Land Ownership Datasets
Scoping Paper on the Readiness of National Statistics Offices to Report on SDG Indicator 1.4.2 in Eight Asian Countries

indicators.justification:
The Philippines has had a long track record of good practice when it comes to making public budget (1) and expenditure data available to the public. The challenge now is to create tools to optimize the view of the annual gigantic dataset to be more purposeful, like based on sector, services, and those which will be of interest to the people.

Source:

(1) https://dbm.gov.ph/index.php/budget-documents/previous-years

evidence.title: 2021 General Appropriations Act (Philippines)
2021 National Expenditure Program

responses.response_text: Data is available from government, or because of government actions.
responses.subquestion_text: Is this data available online in any form?
There is structured data available on the executive budget proposal in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data available on amended budgets (when applicable) or amendments of the enacted budget.
There is structured data available on the approved or enacted budget in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about government budget execution or spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis, including spending in annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about the government's extrabudgetary funds spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about the government's social security spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about public corporations' spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
Budget entries have administrative classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have economic classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have functional classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have program classifications according to an internationally agreed standard.
Information about individual financial transactions or expenditures is available at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification level.
Data is disaggregated by cross-cutting programs, or issues such as SDGs, climate action, gender budgeting, etc,
The data contains common identifiers to connect budget and budget performance data.
The data contains identifiers that can be used to connect budget data with data on major projects (e.g., infrastructure construction) and procurement processes.
Dataset is available free of charge.
Data is openly licensed.
Data is available in all the country’s official or national languages. If the country has no official or national languages, data is available in the major languages of the country.
There are accessible and open official tools available to help users explore data.
Data is timely and updated.
Historical data is available that allows users to track change over time.
Data is provided in machine-readable format(s)
The machine-readable dataset is available as a whole

indicators.justification:
While the law mentions making asset declarations available to the public, the Philippine government has not developed its policy enough to publish it as open data, or require complete public publishing of such info at all. In fact, at the current situation, the Philippine government has kept most asset declarations away from public view (1).

Source:

(1) https://pcij.org/article/6743/duterte-saln-restricted-pcij-request

indicators.justification:
While sometimes lacking and mostly difficult to connect with each other, public procurement data is available mainly in the Philippine Government E-Procurement System and Government Procurement Policy Board, among other regulatory and information custody agencies (1). There is much room for improvement when it comes to improving the open data practice for the benefit of the people.

Sources:

(1) https://schoolofdata.org/2019/03/06/public-procurement-data-in-the-philippines-and-where-to-find-it/

evidence.title: Philippine Government E-Procurement System Open Data page
Philippine Government Procurement Policy Board website
Republic Act No. 9184 - Government Procurement Reform Act

responses.response_text: Data is available from government, or because of government actions.
responses.subquestion_text: Is this data available online in any form?
Procurement related to goods and services is included.
Procurement related to public works is included.
The planning phase is covered.
The tender stage is covered.
The award stage is covered.
The contract implementation stage is covered.
The data contains identifiers or other features that connect together data on each stage of a single procurement process.
The data contains names and unique identifiers for companies awarded contracts.
The data contains start and end dates for tender processes and/or contracts.
The data contains the value (cost) of each tender, award, or contract
The data contains, or can be linked to, information on spending against the contract.
The data contains a description of the goods, services or works being procured.
The data is published according to one or more relevant data standards.
The data contains links to accessible tender, award, or contract documentation
Dataset is available free of charge.
Data is openly licensed.

Local governments are still learning about FOI at the moment (1). Open Data is another level of learning and exposure for them, which the government will hopefully put attention to next.

responses.response_text: There is no evidence of capability to effectively manage data.
responses.subquestion_text: To what extent do city, regional, and local governments have the capability to effectively manage data?
There is evidence of local governments having open data initiatives.
There is evidence of local governments having current open data policies in place.
There is evidence of local governments having rules and or guidance in place to provide a comprehensive framework for data sharing.
There is evidence of local governments having rules and or guidance in place for consistent data management and publication.
There is evidence of local governments providing training to civil servants on data literacy and skills.
There is evidence of local governments providing support for data reuse.

indicators.justification:
Possibly due to the COVID-19 pandemic, training for civil servants on data literacy and skills were not done that much in 2020-2021 compared to other years amid skeleton workforces and shift in focus to address the pandemic. While the government encourages civil servants to take online learning and development opportunities instead (1), the challenge to participate on such when internet connection is still a challenge for some (2) makes it unfeasible for most. 

Some training opportunities also exist but with paid attendance, which adds another barrier for accessible learning toward professional development. The challenge now for capacity-building agencies like the Development Academy of the Philippines would be to keep these training opportunities cheap or free and accessible to all public servants across the country.

Sources:

(1) https://contactcenterngbayan.gov.ph/8-news/311-take-advantage-of-online-learning-civil-servants-told

(2) https://cnnphilippines.com/life/culture/2020/5/20/internet-access-pandemic.html

Lobbying data and political finance data share common identifiers for lobbyist clients and party and campaign donors.
Lobbying registers and public consultation data use common identifiers for regulations.
Asset declarations and political finance disclosures share common identifiers for interests, assets, and liabilities.
The various datasets share common identifiers for legal persons associated with donations, interests, assets, liabilities, and lobbying activities.
The key datasets for the political integrity and company information modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and land modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public finance modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public procurement modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.

responses.response_text: There is no consistency of identifiers or identification systems.

indicators.justification:
As the overall governing body of partnerships and corporations (1), the Philippines' Securities and Exchange Commission has set out new guidelines on collecting beneficial ownership information. However, its availability to the public is still a work in progress, as SEC's public database has been moving towards more opaqueness in the past years, with it currently being unavailable for some time now (2).

Sources:

(1) https://www.sec.gov.ph/about-us/power-and-functions/

indicators.justification:
With open data and FOI still being issued in the Philippines, data management and publication standards should not be expected. 

Even the Philippine Statistics Authority does not have a clear policy on this, based on its mandated law. This reality also affects how the government provides better policies and protections for vulnerable sectors like PWDs (1).

Source:

(1) https://www.philstar.com/headlines/2021/02/18/2078656/poor-data-management-still-problem-house-panel-pwds

responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
There are minimum standards for metadata when government data is catalogued or published.
There is a standardised process for publishing and updating published government data.
There are technical standards, including common data models, codelists, and identifiers for management and publication of government data.
There are clearly documented quality control processes for government data.
There are clearly documented processes for soliciting and integrating feedback from external users to improve data quality.

indicators.justification:
The mention of "data sharing" in Philippine government has been in the case of data privacy (1), and not necessarily as a separate concept related to better access of the public to timely, accurate, and contextual government information. 

However, National Privacy Commission's data sharing circular may be enough as an initial data sharing guideline, providing guidelines for all personal information collectors, but can definitely be improved in policy and practice in the coming years -- especially in the aspect of government-to-government data sharing in relation to public services.

Source:
(1) http://ateneo.edu/udpo/article/Does-the-Data-Privacy-Act-inhibit-data-sharing

evidence.title: National Privacy Commission - Data Sharing Agreement MC
Implementing Rules and Regulations - Data Privacy Act of 2012

indicators.justification:
Republic Act No. 10173 or the Data Privacy Act of 2012, along with its Implementing Rules and Regulations and the Advisory Opinions being released by the National Privacy Commission, provide a detailed framework for protecting personal data. 

However, what is written in policy does not necessarily reflect in practice, as leaks of COVID-19 patient information (1) remain with impunity, and exacting accountability in relation to massive data breaches in the past years remain unreported.

Source: (1) https://www.rappler.com/newsbreak/in-depth/unauthorized-disclosure-covid-19-patients-identities-continues-npc

The framework requires data controllers to notify an appropriate authority of data breaches.

Where does this requirement exist?

indicators.justification:
The Department of Information and Communications Technology needs a newer guiding policy for their open data program as their current policy basis is still from the past administration (1). 

The working basis of Open Data in the Philippines is a joint memorandum circular from 2015, released by the Open Data Philippines Task Force back then (JOINT MEMORANDUM CIRCULAR NO. 2015-01)(2). No recent release has been done to reiterate this, but the 2015 circular still serves as the norm on Open Data in the Philippines. Data continues to be uploaded onto the ODPH portal but the Open Data Philippines Task Force appears to have been inactive since 2016, following a shift in government.

Source:

(1) https://data.gov.ph/?q=about_us

(2) https://data.gov.ph/about/joint-memorandum-circular-2014-01-open-data-philippines

evidence.title: JOINT MEMORANDUM CIRCULAR NO. 2014-01 - Open Data Philippines
Guidelines for the Implementation of the Open Government Data General Provision in the 2015 General Appropriations Act

indicators.justification:
The main guiding policy when it comes to Philippine Public Finance would be the highest law of the land itself -- the 1987 Philippine Constitution, specifically Sections 24 and 25. The land's main agency for public finance -- the Department of Budget and Management -- meanwhile, gets its mandate from an ancient policy (Executive Order No. 25, s. 1936).

Sources:

https://www.officialgazette.gov.ph/constitutions/the-1987-constitution-of-the-republic-of-the-philippines/the-1987-constitution-of-the-republic-of-the-philippines-article-vi/

https://www.officialgazette.gov.ph/1936/04/25/executive-order-no-25-s-1936/

Source: https://dbm.gov.ph/index.php/about-us/mandate

Executive Order No. 25, s. 1936

There is evidence of government procurement data being used for red flag analysis.
There is evidence that government procurement data is being analyzed to improve access to procurement opportunities for marginalized groups.
There is evidence of government procurement data being analysed to support sustainable / environmental procurement.
There are examples of government using data in these ways.
There are examples of civil society using data in these ways.
There is evidence of private sector using data in this way
At least one of the examples cited appears to make use of open procurement data.
At least one of the examples identified makes use of open beneficial ownership data.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.
